title: 104_hr1404
content: The policy of the United States aims to end animal suffering caused by steel jaw leghold traps by prohibiting their shipment in interstate or foreign commerce, along with fur articles from animals trapped in such traps. The term "article of fur" in this Act refers to furskins or articles made from furskins. The definition of furskin, raw or dressed, is based on the Tariff Schedules of the United States. The term "interstate or foreign commerce" is also defined within the Act. The term "import" in the Act refers to bringing goods into the United States. The term "person" includes individuals, partnerships, corporations, and federal entities. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. A "steel jaw leghold trap" is a device designed to capture an animal by snapping closed upon the animal's limb. PROHIBITED ACTS AND PENALTIES. The import, export, or shipment of fur derived from animals trapped in steel jaw leghold traps is prohibited. It is also illegal to import or transport steel jaw leghold traps in interstate or foreign commerce. Any person who knowingly violates regulations regarding the import, export, or shipment of fur from animals trapped in steel jaw leghold traps may face fines up to $1,000 for the first offense and up to $5,000 and two years imprisonment for subsequent violations. The Secretary will reward individuals with half of the fine paid for providing information leading to a conviction of a criminal violation under the Act. Government officials are not eligible for rewards. Enforcement of the Act is outlined in Section 5. The Secretary enforces the Act and regulations with the help of other agencies. Judges and magistrates can issue warrants for enforcement within their jurisdictions. Federal agencies and State agencies can be utilized for enforcement purposes. To enforce the Act, individuals can detain, search, and seize packages, make arrests without a warrant, and execute warrants issued by judges or magistrates. Seized items will be held by authorized persons. Any item seized under this Act shall be held by an authorized person pending criminal proceedings or forfeiture. The Secretary may allow the owner to post a bond instead. Forfeited items will be disposed of as prescribed by the Secretary. Any fur or steel jaw leghold trap seized in violation of this Act or its regulations will be forfeited to the United States. The Attorney General can seek to enjoin individuals violating the Act or its regulations. The Secretary will create regulations to enforce the Act, which will take effect one year after its enactment.
